title: How to Make Crab Ravioli

steps.headline: Make a quick roux for the filling.
steps.description: Melt 1/2 tablespoon of unsalted butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Stir in 1/2 tablespoon of all-purpose flour and keep whisking the roux for 30 seconds. Whisk in 1/4 cup (60 ml) of half-and-half or whole milk. Continue to whisk the roux until it thickens which should take about a minute. Turn off the heat and let it cool. This quick roux will keep your crab filling thick and absorb moisture as the ravioli cooks.

steps.headline: Fold in the crab meat and seasonings.
steps.description: Pick over 1/2 pound (226 g) of lump crab meat to remove any shell or cartilage. Add the crab meat to the cooled roux and gently fold in 1/2 teaspoon of Dijon mustard, 1 teaspoon of fresh minced tarragon, and one large minced scallion (only the white part). Add salt and white ground pepper according to your taste. To fold the seasonings, hold a spoon and use a twisting motion to incorporate the seasonings into the thick roux.

steps.headline: Set up a work station.
steps.description: Since you'll be assembling a lot of crab ravioli (about 48), you need to have your wrappers, water, and crap filling all laid out. Get out the 48 wonton wrappers. Set a small prep bowl filled with water on your work surface and get out a pastry brush. Place the crab filling in a bowl on your work surface. You should also line a baking sheet with plastic wrap and set it aside, so you have somewhere to place the filled crab ravioli before they cook.

steps.headline: Fill the wonton wrappers with the crab filling.
steps.description: Practice filling and forming about three ravioli at a time. Get out three wonton wrappers and use the pastry brush to coat them with water. Spoon 1/2 teaspoon to 1 teaspoon of the crab filling onto the middle of each wonton wrapper. If you have someone helping you assemble the crab ravioli, you might have them divide the crab filling into 48 portions. This way, you can quickly fill the ravioli before you seal them up.

steps.headline: Seal the ravioli.
steps.description: Get out three more wonton wrappers. Place one wrapper over each of the filled wrappers. Ensure that you push out any air that might be trapped in between the wrappers. Press the sides of the wonton wrappers, so they seal shut. It's important to work quickly, so the water doesn't dry before the wonton wrappers are sealed shut.

steps.headline: Trim the filled ravioli.
steps.description: Press a 2.5-inch (6.3-cm) round cutter onto each filled wonton. This will give your ravioli a round or fluted shape while trimming away the extra wonton wrapper. Set the prepared ravioli on the baking sheet. Continue to fill, seal, and trim the crab ravioli in small batches until you've assembled all of them.

steps.headline: Boil the crab wonton ravioli.
steps.description: Bring a large sauce pot full salted water to a boil. Carefully add the ravioli and stir them gently. Let the ravioli boil for about three minutes or until they float to the top of the water. Use a slotted spoon to gently scoop them out of the water and into a colander. You can pour the cooked ravioli with the water through a colander, but some of the ravioli may break in the process.

steps.headline: Serve the crab ravioli.
steps.description: Toss your drained crab ravioli with your favorite sauce and serve them right away. Crab ravioli works well with tomato sauce, cream-based sauces, butter sauces, or garlic sauces. If you want to make the crab ravioli in advance, you can assemble them, dust them with flour, and refrigerate them for up to 24 hours. When you're ready to serve them, just remove them from the refrigerator and boil them.

methods.name: Making Crab Pasta Ravioli With Homemade Pasta

steps.headline: Combine the flour and salt.
steps.description: Measure 3/4 cup (90 g) of flour directly onto your work surface and add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to it. Use your hand to make a well in the center of the flour. You can use all-purpose or pasta flour for the dough.

steps.headline: Mix in the oil and egg.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon of olive oil into the well and crack one medium egg into it. You should also add one egg yolk to the wet ingredients. Use your fingers to stir the flour mixture into the wet ingredients in the center, so a shaggy dough forms. You can discard the extra egg white or save it for another recipe.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Keep stretching and folding the dough until it becomes soft and elastic. You should knead it for about 10 minutes. Once the dough is soft, wrap it in plastic wrap and let it rest while you make the filling. Try to let the dough rest for about 20 minutes at room temperature before you stretch or roll it.

steps.headline: Combine the crab filling.
steps.description:
Pick over 3.5 ounces (100 g) of crab meat for shells or cartilage. Place the crab in a small mixing bowl and stir in the seasonings until they're incorporated. You'll need to add:
1 pinch cayenne
1 pinch paprika
1 pinch nutmeg
1 tablespoon melted butter
1 tablespoon finely chopped flat-leaf parsley
Salt and pepper, to taste

steps.headline: Roll the dough.
steps.description: Sprinkle the work surface with flour and place the unwrapped dough on it. Use a rolling pin to roll the dough out to a rectangle. Cut the dough in half and set one half aside. Roll one of the halves out as thinly as you can. If you have a pasta machine or pasta attachment, follow the manufacturer's instructions for rolling out ravioli.

steps.headline: Cut the ravioli.
steps.description: Take a 4-inch (10 cm) round cutter and stamp rounds out of the thinly rolled pasta dough. Sprinkle some flour on a baking sheet, so you can place the cutouts aside while stamping out the rest of the dough. Continue to re-roll and cut the dough until you've used all of it. You'll also want to roll and cut the remaining dough half that you set aside.

steps.headline: Fill the crab ravioli.
steps.description: Measure out one level teaspoon of the crab filling. Hold one of the cutouts and place the teaspoon of filling near the middle. Use your finger or a pastry brush to spread a little water along the edge of the cutout and fold it over, so the ravioli looks like a half-moon. Dust the filled ravioli with a little flour. Ensure that you've pressed the edges well, so a seal is created.

steps.headline: Boil the crab ravioli.
steps.description: Bring a large sauce pot full salted water to a boil. Carefully add the ravioli and stir them gently. Let the ravioli boil for about four minutes or until they float to the top of the water. Use a slotted spoon to gently scoop them out of the water and into a colander. You can pour the cooked ravioli with the water through a colander, but some of the ravioli may break in the process.

steps.headline: Serve the crab ravioli.
steps.description: Toss your drained crab ravioli with your favorite sauce and serve them right away. Fresh pasta crab ravioli tastes great with light, fresh flavors. Try serving the ravioli with lightly sauteed grape tomatoes, olive oil and garlic, or a light white wine sauce. If you want to make the crab ravioli in advance, you can assemble them, dust them with flour, and refrigerate them for up to 24 hours. When you're ready to serve them, just remove them from the refrigerator and boil them.

text:
Making Crab Wonton Ravioli Make a quick roux for the filling. Melt 1/2 tablespoon of unsalted butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Stir in 1/2 tablespoon of all-purpose flour and keep whisking the roux for 30 seconds. Whisk in 1/4 cup (60 ml) of half-and-half or whole milk. Continue to whisk the roux until it thickens which should take about a minute. Turn off the heat and let it cool. This quick roux will keep your crab filling thick and absorb moisture as the ravioli cooks. Fold in the crab meat and seasonings. Pick over 1/2 pound (226 g) of lump crab meat to remove any shell or cartilage. Add the crab meat to the cooled roux and gently fold in 1/2 teaspoon of Dijon mustard, 1 teaspoon of fresh minced tarragon, and one large minced scallion (only the white part). Add salt and white ground pepper according to your taste. To fold the seasonings, hold a spoon and use a twisting motion to incorporate the seasonings into the thick roux. Set up a work station. Since you'll be assembling a lot of crab ravioli (about 48), you need to have your wrappers, water, and crap filling all laid out. Get out the 48 wonton wrappers. Set a small prep bowl filled with water on your work surface and get out a pastry brush. Place the crab filling in a bowl on your work surface. You should also line a baking sheet with plastic wrap and set it aside, so you have somewhere to place the filled crab ravioli before they cook. Fill the wonton wrappers with the crab filling. Practice filling and forming about three ravioli at a time. Get out three wonton wrappers and use the pastry brush to coat them with water. Spoon 1/2 teaspoon to 1 teaspoon of the crab filling onto the middle of each wonton wrapper. If you have someone helping you assemble the crab ravioli, you might have them divide the crab filling into 48 portions. This way, you can quickly fill the ravioli before you seal them up. Seal the ravioli. Get out three more wonton wrappers. Place one wrapper over each of the filled wrappers. Ensure that you push out any air that might be trapped in between the wrappers. Press the sides of the wonton wrappers, so they seal shut. It's important to work quickly, so the water doesn't dry before the wonton wrappers are sealed shut. Trim the filled ravioli. Press a 2.5-inch (6.3-cm) round cutter onto each filled wonton. This will give your ravioli a round or fluted shape while trimming away the extra wonton wrapper. Set the prepared ravioli on the baking sheet. Continue to fill, seal, and trim the crab ravioli in small batches until you've assembled all of them. Boil the crab wonton ravioli. Bring a large sauce pot full salted water to a boil. Carefully add the ravioli and stir them gently. Let the ravioli boil for about three minutes or until they float to the top of the water. Use a slotted spoon to gently scoop them out of the water and into a colander. You can pour the cooked ravioli with the water through a colander, but some of the ravioli may break in the process. Serve the crab ravioli. Toss your drained crab ravioli with your favorite sauce and serve them right away. Crab ravioli works well with tomato sauce, cream-based sauces, butter sauces, or garlic sauces. If you want to make the crab ravioli in advance, you can assemble them, dust them with flour, and refrigerate them for up to 24 hours. When you're ready to serve them, just remove them from the refrigerator and boil them. Making Crab Pasta Ravioli With Homemade Pasta Combine the flour and salt. Measure 3/4 cup (90 g) of flour directly onto your work surface and add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to it. Use your hand to make a well in the center of the flour. You can use all-purpose or pasta flour for the dough. Mix in the oil and egg. Pour 1 tablespoon of olive oil into the well and crack one medium egg into it. You should also add one egg yolk to the wet ingredients. Use your fingers to stir the flour mixture into the wet ingredients in the center, so a shaggy dough forms. You can discard the extra egg white or save it for another recipe. Knead the dough. Keep stretching and folding the dough until it becomes soft and elastic. You should knead it for about 10 minutes. Once the dough is soft, wrap it in plastic wrap and let it rest while you make the filling. Try to let the dough rest for about 20 minutes at room temperature before you stretch or roll it. Combine the crab filling. Pick over 3.5 ounces (100 g) of crab meat for shells or cartilage. Place the crab in a small mixing bowl and stir in the seasonings until they're incorporated. You'll need to add:
1 pinch cayenne
1 pinch paprika
1 pinch nutmeg
1 tablespoon melted butter
1 tablespoon finely chopped flat-leaf parsley
Salt and pepper, to taste Roll the dough. Sprinkle the work surface with flour and place the unwrapped dough on it. Use a rolling pin to roll the dough out to a rectangle. Cut the dough in half and set one half aside. Roll one of the halves out as thinly as you can. If you have a pasta machine or pasta attachment, follow the manufacturer's instructions for rolling out ravioli. Cut the ravioli. Take a 4-inch (10 cm) round cutter and stamp rounds out of the thinly rolled pasta dough. Sprinkle some flour on a baking sheet, so you can place the cutouts aside while stamping out the rest of the dough. Continue to re-roll and cut the dough until you've used all of it. You'll also want to roll and cut the remaining dough half that you set aside. Fill the crab ravioli. Measure out one level teaspoon of the crab filling. Hold one of the cutouts and place the teaspoon of filling near the middle. Use your finger or a pastry brush to spread a little water along the edge of the cutout and fold it over, so the ravioli looks like a half-moon. Dust the filled ravioli with a little flour. Ensure that you've pressed the edges well, so a seal is created. Boil the crab ravioli. Bring a large sauce pot full salted water to a boil. Carefully add the ravioli and stir them gently. Let the ravioli boil for about four minutes or until they float to the top of the water. Use a slotted spoon to gently scoop them out of the water and into a colander. You can pour the cooked ravioli with the water through a colander, but some of the ravioli may break in the process. Serve the crab ravioli. Toss your drained crab ravioli with your favorite sauce and serve them right away. Fresh pasta crab ravioli tastes great with light, fresh flavors. If you want to make the crab ravioli in advance, you can assemble them, dust them with flour, and refrigerate them for up to 24 hours. When you're ready to serve them, just remove them from the refrigerator and boil them.
